item.description:
After a brief hiatus, we resume our foray into the classics. And what better to read next, but Flaubert's undisputed masterpiece "Madame Bovary". I came across this quote that might tempt those among you hesitant to pick it up:

"What is remarkable in Madame Bovary is that its mediocre beings, with their earthbound ambitions and pedestrian problems, impress us, by virtue of the structure and the writing that create them, as beings who are out of the ordinary within their ordinary manner of being." - Mario Vargas Llosa

Yes, it is all about the writing, so find yourself a decent translation. And if you have already read and reread this, like I have, I'd suggest taking a look at Julian Barnes' "Flaubert's Parrot" for all kinds of insights into Flaubert's world and beyond.

group.name: Classic Books: Book Club for Die-hard Readers

item.name: Flaubert: Madame Bovary
